awd_titl_txt: CC-NIE Networking Infrastructure: Caltech's High-performance OPtical Integrated Network (CHOPIN)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Caltech High-performance OPtical Integrated Network (CHOPIN) delivers the most advanced networking technologies to the Caltech campus as a single concept in support of several leading research groups. CHOPIN deploys Software-Defined Networking (SDN) capable switches on the campus, as well as a 100Gbps link between Caltech and CENIC, supporting direct connectivity to the California OpenFlow Testbed Network (COTN), a connection to the Internet2 Advanced Layer 2 Services (AL2S) network, as well as other major Research and Education networks. In this way, CHOPIN supports leading edge Research and Development activities in the networking area, as well as high-throughput computing (HTC) based applications and research using large data volumes and velocities.

The ScienceDMZ concept integrated into the design allows for a unified, flexible, yet high-performance system supporting both the campus General Purpose Network and HTC applications on the same underlying infrastructure. The new 100G capability paves the way for integration also with routed high performance services such as the CENIC HPR-L3 and Internet2 Advanced Layer 3 Services. The uplink is complemented by 100G and 40G links to a set of OpenFlow capable switches to each of several major research groups.

The infrastructure improvements and leveraged software and methods benefit all of the Caltech campus, and explicitly groups involved in Big Data and high-throughput research, such as high energy physics, astronomy (LIGO, LSST), seismology, geodetic Earth satellite observations and many other pure and applied science disciplines, including computer science and applied mathematics.

por.por_cntn:
The Caltech High performance OPtical Integrated Network (CHOPIN) project made substantial progress, since its inception, towards its principal goal of creating an advanced, software driven intelligent network environment and making it available to the research groups with large scale needs for accessing and transporting terascale to petascale datasets to and from the campus, and over regional, national and international networks serving high energy physics, astrophysics and other disciplines of data intensive sciences. In addition to setting up the environment and developing state of the art software tools and applications, the Caltech HEP group that leads the project has provided advice and direct help on the design, deployment and use of high throughput data transfer servers, as well as the tools needed to automate these transfers.

The project brings together several components: the deployment of a 100 gigabit/sec wide area network link to the campus, along with servers capable of stable data transfers at managed levels up to the 100 gigabit/sec range; the deployment and the use in production of advanced network monitoring tools; and providing access to the new generation of advanced programmable network services through the installation of devices and software at the campus edge, as well as a state of the art programmable network R&D testbed that supports and advance the new network paradigm. While high energy physics is the initial primary use case, the facilities, software tools and methods, and training in advanced server design and high throughput applications is available to all other research groups.

In the course of this project the Caltech high energy physics team has worked closely with collaborating groups involved in the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Observatory (LIGO) and the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC) on the Caltech campus, as well as the Pacific Research Platform involving many University of California campuses, and has collaborated with other research teams working on the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) program, as well as the teams developing in the US and Brazil advanced network capabilities for the future Large Synoptic Space Telescope (LSST).

This project, and allied projects of the Caltech team, have been made possible through a strong and wide-ranging collaboration among dozens of teams including university and laboratory-based science research and network engineering teams, regional, national and international research and education network teams and industry. The CHOPIN project in particular has, in turn, been one of the key projects strengthening this collaborative effort, making possible new concepts and advanced developments to be accomplished on behalf of the major science programs mentioned, as well as the broader science and engineering research community.
